answers.text: the Governor of New South Wales, Sir Richard Bourke

qas.question: Who was Melbourne named in honor of?

answers.text: the British Prime Minister of the day, William Lamb, 2nd Viscount Melbourne

qas.question: What year was Melbourne officially declared a city?
What year did Melbourne cease in serving as the nations interim seat of government?
Melbourne became the capital of what colony in 1851?

context: Founded by free settlers from the British Crown colony of Van Diemen's Land on 30 August 1835, in what was then the colony of New South Wales, it was incorporated as a Crown settlement in 1837. It was named "Melbourne" by <a0_0>the Governor of New South Wales, Sir Richard Bourke<a0_0/>, in honour of <a1_0>the British Prime Minister of the day, William Lamb, 2nd Viscount Melbourne<a1_0/>. It was officially declared a city by Queen Victoria in <a2_0>1847<a2_0/>, after which it became the capital of the newly founded colony of <a4_0>Victoria<a4_0/> in 1851. During the Victorian gold rush of the 1850s, it was transformed into one of the world's largest and wealthiest cities. After the federation of Australia in 1901, it served as the nation's interim seat of government until <a3_0>1927<a3_0/>.
